newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Easdaq sees 5 stocks soon, liquidity "no problem".
newsitem.headline: Easdaq sees 5 stocks soon, liquidity "no problem".

text.p: Europe's new growth stocks market Easdaq, which went live on November 27 and now lists two stocks, hopes be to quoting five by the year-end, the European Asociation of Securities Dealers (EASD) said on Tuesday.

"Nasdaq-quoted companies are still looking for (Easdaq- registered) market makers, but with five companies up in a month it's still pretty good going," EASD director Chris Pickles told Reuters, speaking on behalf of Easdaq.

As recently as mid-November Easdaq had forecast up to 15 stocks would be trading by end-December, some of which would simply be dual-listings of stocks quoted on Nasdaq -- a move designed to boost liquidity on the new European exchange.
But many of the latter which showed an interest have found a shortage of European market makers with knowledge of the 80 or so European companies listed on the U.S. growth stocks market.

Pickles said, however, liquidity was not proving a problem in terms of executing trades on Easdaq without causing price instability. It had seen "tens of millions of dollars of trade so far, and hundreds of cross-border trades a day."

First to kick off on Easdaq was Dr Solomon's Group Plc, a U.K. based anti-virus software developer which launched on New York's Nasdaq the previous day. It was swiftly followed by Belgian biotechnology firm Innogenetics.
After two weeks, though, Dr Solomon's stock was unchanged from its listing price at $17, and Innogenetics stood around $11.75, just beneath its launch price of $12.

Undaunted by this low-key start, Belgian software company Artwork Systems Group NV launches on Wednesday. Its initial public share offer was more than twice oversubscribed and its shares are priced at $10.50 each.

French "smart-card" maker ActivCard SA has its sights on a launch around December 16. Another French firm -- low-cost flat screen technology company PixTech already traded on Nasdaq -- is aiming for around December 23.
Easdaq was still on target to have at least 50 companies listed by the end of 1997.
To be admitted, firms must be supported by at least two Easdaq-registered market makers. They must have total assets of 3.5 million Ecus($4.3 million) and capital and reserves of two million Ecus.
Pickles said more Nasdaq brokers were looking at setting up offices in Europe for the purpose of Easdaq market-making, or at going into joint ventures with European houses.

One such operation set up at the start of the year was Hambrecht & Quist Saint Dominique in Paris -- one of Dr Solomon's Easdaq market-makers -- which is an investment services joint venture between U.S. bank Hambrecht & Quist and two units of France's Credit National.
The Easdaq project, modelled on Nasdaq, originated from contacts between the European Venture Capital Association, the European Commission and various market players.
Nasdaq is one of Easdaq's 91 shareholders which brought about 370 million Belgian francs ($11.6 million) together to finance its launch.
